unit_learning_outcomes.description: Competently perform a history and orthopaedic physical examination for common musculoskeletal conditions.
Develop a respect and empathy for patients, and an ethical and professional attitude to health care, which also includes fostering a commitment to continuing professional development.
Apply clinical reasoning skills to determine if a patient is a suitable candidate for chiropractic care, or organise an appropriate referral where necessary

Draw on acquired theoretical knowledge in order to tailor the history taking process and physical examination to the patient, and from this, develop a list of differential diagnoses, a working diagnosis, and a clinical management plan.
Understand, interpret and apply the principles of diagnostic test accuracy as they relate to the orthopaedic physical examination.

Participate in practical sessions in which the knowledge acquired from texts and lectures is applied in a group situation. Reason, question and communicate your knowledge to tutors and fellow students.
Find, select and critique relevant clinical research literature to inform the diagnosis and management of common musculoskeletal conditions.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: 1 hour per week reading for 10 weeks

assessments.description: Students will be tested on their theoretical knowledge of diagnostic test accuracy as it applies to orthopaedic physical assessment.

Students will be tested on their theoretical knowledge of common musculoskeletal conditions and associated history and examination findings, and results from paraclinical investigations. Students will also be asked to apply this knowledge to clinical case scenarios.
Students will be assessed on their competency in performing orthopaedic physical assessment.
Students will be assessed on their competency in performing orthopaedic physical assessment.

data.description: This unit introduces a student to the common musculoskeletal conditions relevant to chiropractors in primary care settings. Students are instructed on how to interpret history, examination and paraclinical study findings, and how to plan and execute an orthopaedic physical examination for common musculoskeletal conditions. The knowledge and skills acquired during this unit are fundamental for developing diagnostic proficiency in chiropractic practice.
data.title: Orthopaedic Physical Assessment
